abstract.para: Learn the difference between &sudo; and su commands.

topic.para: To log in as &rootuser; you can preface your command with one of the following options:

listitem.para: su: allows you to run a command as &rootuser; but requires you to know the &rootuser; password.
&sudo;: allows you to run a command as &rootuser; and, depending on it's configuration, it may not require the &rootuser; password.

topic.para: You can execute single commands as &rootuser; or another user, based on your settings in the /etc/sudoers file. The sudoers files are files that Linux administrators use to allocate system rights to the system users. This allows the administrator to control who does what. If you want to securely execute a command as a &rootuser; user, you must always use the &sudo; command. The main difference between &sudo; and su commands is that su elevates privileges only during the shell session while &sudo; elevates privileges only for the specific command that you execute.
